item.title: California and Nevada Get 200 Mbps Bandwidth over Copper
item.description:
The demand for business bandwidth has increased significantly over the past ten years. Companies that once relied on T1 lines (1.5 to 12 Mbps) or DS3 (45 Mbps) now require speeds exceeding 100 Mbps to accommodate high-definition video, large datasets, and cloud-based services. Obtaining up to 200 Mbps over multiple copper pairs is now much simpler for businesses in California and Nevada. While achieving such speeds with fiber optic connections (SONET or Ethernet over Fiber) is not difficult, the installation of fiber optic cables presents a significant obstacle...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/california-and-nevada-get-200-mbps-bandwidth-over-copper/

item.title: Low Latency Fiber Network For Orange County
item.description:
There’s a rising demand for high-bandwidth, low-latency internet connectivity from businesses, particularly in sectors like finance, automation, cloud computing, and medical imaging. This surge is driving the expansion of fiber optic networks, with a prime example being the ongoing development in the Los Angeles metropolitan area. AboveNet, a prominent fiber optic network provider in the US and Europe, is constructing a major “feeder ring” in Orange County, California. This ring will connect various business locations, including office buildings, data centers, and carrier hotels, to an existing fiber optic backbone already serving the Irvine and Costa Mesa business districts...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/low-latency-fiber-network-for-orange-county/
